hackathon-description-text: From fake news detection, to social networking, to tracking personal data, the role of tech in media is becoming increasingly important. This year TigerHacks is partnering with the

hackathon-judges.judge-role: Associate Teaching Professor, University of Missouri
Associate Professor - MU School of Journalism
Software Architect - Veterans United & Computer Science Instructor - MU

hackathon-rules: You can build whatever you want: websites, programs, mobile apps, anything! However, all code must be written during the hackathon - feel free to use open source libraries and APIs.

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: Each team member gets first pick of one of the following: 4 Nintendo Switches with Zelda, $1024 cash to split, and 4 Amazon Echos.
Each team member gets second pick of one of the following: 4 Nintendo Switches with Zelda, $1024 cash to split, and 4 Amazon Echos.
Each team member gets second pick of one of the following: 4 Nintendo Switches with Zelda, $1024 cash to split, and 4 Amazon Echos.
Microsoft sponsored prize awarded for best use of the Microsoft Graph API. First place team will receive 2 surface books.
Microsoft sponsored prize awarded for best use of the Microsoft Graph API. Second place team will receive drones.
Best project made by first-time hackathon participants. 4 x $128 Amazon giftcards.

hackathon-prizes.prize-title: Best IoT Hack Using a Qualcomm Device
Amazon Web Services - Best Use of AWS
Best website submitted on a .tech domain

hackathon-judging-criteria.judging-criterion: Does this hack solve a real problem?
Was this hack challenging to make?
Is the hack pleasant and usable?
Does this project have the potential to make an impact?

hackathon-description-header: The University of Missouri's Largest Hackathon and Programming Competition
